keynote-0.name: Day 1 Keynote
keynote-0.description: A round-up of the web platform's latest advancements and the evolving landscape. The keynote also covers the Chrome team's continued investment towards moving the platform forward and supporting the community.

speakers.name: Ben Galbraith
speakers.bio: Ben Galbraith is the Product Management Director for the Web Platform at Google. His past roles have included heading Product and Design for Walmart Global eCommerce as well as leadership roles at HP / Palm, Mozilla, MediaOcean, and several startups. Ben has been writing code since he was six and started his first business at ten. He lives in Palo Alto with his wife and eight children.

speakers.name: Dion Almaer
speakers.bio: Dion Almaer is striving for a better Web as Director of the Web Developer Ecosystem in Chrome. He works on tools, services, and libraries that aim to make it easier for developers to build successful products that load fast and delight users. He also enjoys working with developers throughout the ecosystem, across many of Googleâ€™s Web initiatives beyond Chrome itself. Previously, he has enjoyed building software products and platforms from his own startups to companies such as Mozilla (developer tools), Palm (webOS), and Walmart Labs (VPE for native mobile and Web).

why-the-web-matters.name: Get Down to Business: Why the Web Matters
why-the-web-matters.description: Music? Coffee? Ideas? By focusing on speed and taking advantage of the Webâ€™s expanding capabilities, three global businesses found meaningful engagement with new and existing users everywhere. Hear directly from Spotify, Starbucks and Pinterest about the unique methods theyâ€™ve used to build and continually improve their PWAs and as a result, achieved growth and business success.

speakers.name: Aanchal Bahadur
speakers.bio: Aanchal Bahadur has been at Google for eight years, contributing to the core of Google's scale in Ad Operations and managing talented YouTube creators on the Creator and Artist Development Partnerships team in India. For the past three years, she's been leading business development for Chrome/Web Platform driving adoption for modern web tech including - PWAs (#modernweb), web media (#nobuffering), and AMP4Email (#dynamicmail), to move the open web platform forward. In her free time, you'll find her reading, writing, or having a conversation about how dogs > people.

speakers.name: Zack Argyle
speakers.bio: Zack Argyle leads the web platform team at Pinterest with a deep passion for fast, engaging PWAs.

speakers.name: David Brunelle
speakers.bio: David is an engineering leader who believes in the ability of digital products to improve the lives of people in both big and small ways. Heâ€™s been building products for the Web since the days of table-based layouts and transparent gifs. Today, David leads the Starbucks digital products engineering team where he is focused on extending the Starbucks experience to all of the digital touch points that matter to Starbucksâ€™ customers including web, native, and voice.

speakers.name: Matt Rizzo
speakers.bio: Matt Rizzo is a Senior Product Manager on the Growth Opportunities team at Spotify. His teamâ€™s focus is on using the power of the Web to drive sustained user growth around the world. Most recently, his team launched a mobile web Spotify player to extend access beyond native apps. In his free time, Matt enjoys running and cheering on the New York Knicks.

speed-tooling.name: State of the Union for Speed Tooling
speed-tooling.description: Measuring, optimizing, and monitoring user experience on the Web has never been easier. Learn about the latest changes in performance tooling, and how to meaningfully incorporate lab and field data into your development workflow. Paul and Elizabeth share the latest developments in Lighthouse, DevTools profiling tools, PageSpeed Insights, Chrome UX Report, and key performance metrics.

speakers.name: Paul Irish
speakers.bio: Paul Irish is a front-end developer who loves the Web. He works on Lighthouse, Chrome DevTools, and performance metrics. Elizabeth Sweeny is a product manager on the Chrome Platform team, working on Lighthouse, CrUX, and other developer insights products.

speakers.name: Elizabeth Sweeny
speakers.bio: Elizabeth Sweeny is a product manager on the Chrome Platform team, working on Lighthouse, CrUX, and other developer insights products.

speed-essentials.name: Speed Essentials: Key Techniques for Fast Websites
speed-essentials.description: The bad news: JavaScript, images, and web fonts often bloat modern web pages. The good news: Thereâ€™s probably a ton of room to improve the performance of your site.   Katie and Houssein guide you through the key techniques in JavaScript, images, [CSS] and web fonts that you can use to maximize the performance of your site.

speakers.name: Houssein Djirdeh
speakers.bio: Houssein works on the performance team at Chrome. He is passionate about progressive enhancement and building for the mobile web.

speakers.name: Katie Hempenius
speakers.bio: Katie is an engineer working on making the Web faster with the Chrome team. Previously, she built things for Google Ad Exchange and Fitbit.

caching-strategies.name: Building Faster, More Resilient Apps with Service Worker: A Caching Strategy Deep Dive
caching-strategies.description: Because most users access the Web on the go, it's critical that we deliver experiences that load quickly and run smoothly, regardless of network conditions. And with service worker now supported in all modern browsers, we can leverage it as a core part of our application architecture and performance strategy.  But not all service worker implementations are created equal, and they can offer vastly different performance benefits. Every prefetch and cache decision comes with speed vs. freshness and bandwidth vs. storage trade offs. Join us to discover how to evaluate and build different service worker flows for your app, giving the best experience for your users.

speakers.name: Ewa Gasperowicz
speakers.bio: Ewa is a developer platform engineer at Google Web team. A front-end engineer, focused mainly on making the Web faster and more user friendly. Interested in Progressive Web Apps development and analysis, EWA is always keen to investigate common scenarios and emerging app design patterns.

speakers.name: Phil Walton
speakers.bio: Philip is a senior developer programs engineer for Chrome with a focus on web performance and tooling. Prior to working at Google, Philip was lead front-end software engineer at AppFolio where he built component libraries and tools for a variety of different web teams. Philip also has experience working in agencies, with non-profit organizations, and as a freelancer.

smooth-moves.name: Smooth Moves: Rendering at the Speed of Right Â®
smooth-moves.description: Follow us as we refactor a microinteraction to unblock threads, unblock users, and crank it up to 60fps. Once the siteâ€™s resources have been delivered quickly, how do we ensure that we keep that high bar for performance? We need to understand rendering and interaction within the page.

speakers.name: Jason Miller
speakers.bio: Jason is with Web DevRel at Google, working on making the Web faster. Created Preact and a few other things.

speakers.name: Adam Argyle
speakers.bio: Adam is a UX Engineer on Google Cloud; Developer += Designer; parentNode + 2 leafs; CSS/JS addict; fullstack+Ui hax0r; repeat(âˆž, [empathize, define, design, develop, deploy]); ðŸ––

complex-js-web-apps.name: Complex JS-heavy Web Apps, Avoiding the Slow
complex-js-web-apps.description: If you can do it without JavaScript, that's usually the fastest path. But what about when JavaScript is the only way? In this session we take a JavaScript-heavy PWA and make it load in less than 5 seconds on 2G, using Web Assembly, workers, and web components.

speakers.name: Jake Archibald
speakers.bio: Jake works in Google Chromeâ€™s developer relations team, working on specs, testing implementations, and ensuring developers have tools to make their jobs less painful. Heâ€™s a big fan of time-to-render optimisations, progressive enhancement, and all of that responsive stuff.

speakers.name: Mariko Kosaka
speakers.bio: Mariko Kosaka is a software engineer who loves data and knitting. When she is not coding applications for other people, she uses code to help her design textiles, and organize local meetup BrooklynJS.

modern-web-media.name: Building Modern Web Media Experiences: Picture-in-Picture and AV1
modern-web-media.description: Learn about how the latest media-related capabilities on the web platform can be used to build efficient and delightful web media experiences. This talk covers both APIs (such as Picture-in-Picture) and codecs (AV1), reviewing some of the nuances of how they can be successfully implemented, along with examples and demos.

speakers.name: FranÃ§ois Beaufort
speakers.bio: He loves to dive into Chromium source code and share his findings.

speakers.name: Angie Bird
speakers.bio: Angie is a software engineer in Google. She has been working on AV1 core design for more than three years. Prior to her software engineering career at Google, she studied in the Computer Science Master Program at NYU.

modern-ecommerce.name: Modern Websites for E-commerce in the Real World
modern-ecommerce.description: While the Web has provided increased capabilities, success for real-world ecommerce requires taking a measured approach. In this session, you'll hear how some ecommerce companies are tackling challenges like organizational complexity, legacy code, measurement, prioritization, and more to provide better experiences to their web users and prepare for future needs and demand. You'll also learn how AMP and PWA have played a role in shaping these modern consumer journeys.

speakers.name: Cheney Tsai
speakers.bio: Cheney is a solutions consultant at Google, currently focused on advancing the mobile web. He works closely with top partners to adopt modern web technologies (like PWA and AMP) and raise the bar of mobile UX. Prior to Google, Cheney was an engineer at Pickie (acquired by RetailMeNot) and a consultant at Deloitte.

speakers.name: Ramya Raghavan
speakers.bio: Ramya is a technical consultant at Google working with e-commerce and Pharma partners on improving the mobile web experience through the use of modern web technologies (like PWA, AMP, open web APIs). Prior to Google, Ramya was a full-stack developer at USA Today (Gannett), PBDewberry and Wipro Technologies.

progressive-cms.name: Progressive Content Management Systems
progressive-cms.description: Content Management Systems (CMS) are software platforms designed to simplify the creation and management of websites and their content. Nowadays, about 50% of websites are powered by some sort of CMS platform. In this talk, we discuss our experience moving a complex CMS (i.e. WordPress) forward along the Progressive Web Road by integrating modern capabilities (e.g. Service Worker API) and progressive technologies (e.g. AMP) into its platform and ecosystem, and how the lessons learned can be applied to other CMSes.

speakers.name: Alberto Medina
speakers.bio: Alberto Medina is a Developer Advocate in the Web Content Ecosystems Team at Google, focusing on AMP, Progressive Technologies, and Content Management Systems. Alberto is a Computer Scientist by training and has worked in academic environments, research labs, startups, medium companies (~300M users), and large companies (~1B+ users). Passionate about enabling awesome web experiences for all users.

speakers.name: Weston Ruter
speakers.bio: Weston Ruter is a Developer Programs Engineer working on the Content Ecosystems team at Google. For the past decade he has worked extensively with WordPress, including the development of extensions and leading a release of the core CMS. During the past year he has been working to improve the user experience for a third of the Web by advancing AMP and PWA in WordPress.

discoverable-modern-web.name: Making Modern Web Content Discoverable for Search
discoverable-modern-web.description: Many modern JavaScript frameworks render their HTML content on the client-side assuming that every environment that is accessing their pages is as modern as they are. However, many search engines â€“ including Google Search â€“ do not behave exactly the same as a userâ€™s browser.  In this session, you will learn some facts about Google Search, its rendering pipeline and the various tools which can help you diagnose the gap between what your users see versus what Google Search sees. You have built a fast & engaging website â€“ letâ€™s make sure itâ€™s discoverable too.

speakers.name: Martin Splitt
speakers.bio: Martin is a developer advocate on the Webmaster Trends Analyst team at Google Switzerland.  In this role, he helps developers and content creators to build great content on the Web. He is involved with the W3C as well as the global web and JavaScript developer community, working to keep the Web open.

speakers.name: Tom Greenaway
speakers.bio: Tom Greenaway is a Developer Advocate for Chrome & the Web. His focus is on web & HTML gaming. He is also an expert on the indexability of JavaScript-powered websites. Before joining Google he ran his own independent game development studio and created the multi award-winning mobile game "Duet" which was downloaded over 15 million times.

break-after-party-0.name: After Party
break-after-party-0.description: Registered attendees are invited to join us for an onsite afterparty to enjoy food, drinks, music, games, and more. Don't forget your badge! It is required for entry.

keynote-1.name: Day 2 Keynote
keynote-1.description: Join us for a look at web frameworks and the web platform and how they can be stronger togetherâ€“creating great user experiences at scale! Speaking of user experience: Weâ€™ve talked about things like jank and 60 frames per seconds for years, but some of these things remain hard to reliably achieve on the web. With a new set of web standards this is changing, and weâ€™re super excited to introduce them to you!

speakers.name: Malte Ubl
speakers.bio: Malte is a Principal Engineer at Google working on JavaScript infrastructure, a member of the AMP Project Technical Steering Committee, and helps curate JSConf EU in Berlin.

speakers.name: Nicole Sullivan
speakers.bio: Nicole is a PM on Chrome at Google. OOCSS, CSSLint, Smush It, Dr Frankenstyle, typeOmatic. CSSConf founder, author, speaker.

feature-policy.name: Feature Policy & the Well-Lit Path for Web Development
feature-policy.description: Feature Policy is a new primitive which allows developers to selectively enable, disable, and modify the behavior of certain APIs and features in the browser. It's like CSP, but for features & APIs! Teams can use new tools like Feature Policy and the Reporting API to catch errors before they grow out of control, ensure site performance stays high, keep code quality healthy, and help avoid the web's biggest footguns.

speakers.name: Jason Chase
speakers.bio: Jason leads a Chrome team that helps developers understand and control the features available on the web platform. Prior to Google, Jason was building enterprise-class systems delivered on the web, experiencing the challenges of web development directly. Jason has computer science degrees (BMath, MMath) from the University of Waterloo.

layered-apis.name: virtual-scroller: Let there be less (DOM)
layered-apis.description: Rendering performance is mainly a function of how much you render - too much DOM will slow your site to a crawl. Native platforms actually have the same problem, but they stay fast by promoting virtual scrolling: rendering just enough content to fill the screen and continuously updating as the user scrolls. On todayâ€™s Web, virtualization breaks basic features like links and find-in-page, but hope is in sight. Weâ€™ll take an early peek at an effort to add a first-class virtual scroller to HTML, building on an exciting new platform concept called Layered APIs.

speakers.name: Gray Norton
speakers.bio: Gray is a passionate Web advocate and an engineering manager on the Chrome team. Prior to joining Google he led the framework team at webOS, helping developers build apps for several generations of phones, tablets, TVs and watches. In past lives, he has worked on software tools for creating chatbots, 3D games and pretty pictures. When not at work, Gray enjoys spending time with his family and occasionally singing.

scheduling-on-off-main-thread.name: A Quest to Guarantee Responsiveness: Scheduling On and Off the Main Thread
scheduling-on-off-main-thread.description: To achieve a truly responsive experience, developers have to execute their code in 10ms chunks. Thatâ€™s nearly impossible. In this talk, we'll explore two high-level strategies: Main thread scheduling, and moving work into backgrounds threads. Weâ€™ll dive into our latest performance research on multi-threading Javascript, demystify when to utilize web workers, and dive into what it really takes to guarantee responsiveness. Finally, we'll introduce a few exciting new proposals that we'd love your feedback on.

speakers.name: Shubhie Panicker
speakers.bio: Shubhie Panicker, Staff Software Engineer driving performance related efforts on Chromeâ€™s Web Platform team -- working on web standards and chromium implementation. Prior to Chrome, she worked on server infrastructure and web frameworks for products like Google Search, Google Photos, and so on.

speakers.name: Jason Miller
speakers.bio: Jason is with Web DevRel at Google, working on making the Web faster. Created Preact and a few other things.

lights-camera-action.name: Architecting Web Apps - Lights, Camera, Action!
lights-camera-action.description: Architecting web apps continues to be challenging, whether it's accounting for performance, the latest and greatest platform APIs, or simply trying to figure out what part of the app should do what!  In this talk, we explore how you can architect apps for maximum flexibility, and to that end we're going to reintroduce something that's 45-years old which might, in the end, pave the way for the future of web apps.

speakers.name: Paul Lewis
speakers.bio: Prior to Chrome, she worked on server infrastructure and web frameworks for products like Google Search, Google Photos etc.

speakers.name: Surma
speakers.bio: Surma is an engineer working with the Chrome team. He likes to cut himself on the bleeding edge, goes full-stack every once in a while and prefers good code over functional one.

web-packaging-portals.name: From Low Friction to Zero Friction with Web Packaging and Portals
web-packaging-portals.description: In this talk, weâ€™ll look at emerging technologies to build better web experiences. Web packaging enables a next level of content portability that can be used to speed up content delivery or improve modes of content consumption, such as offline. Furthermore, by combining web packaging with a new primitive called Portals, weâ€™ll show how we can take the webâ€™s low friction trait a notch further with zero-friction user experiences.

speakers.name: Kinuko Yasuda
speakers.bio: Kinuko is a software engineer at Google working on Chrome. She is leading loading related implementation projects for Chrome, like Service Workers, Web Packaging, and various loading improvements.

speakers.name: Rudy Galfi
speakers.bio: Rudy Galfi is the lead product manager for the AMP Project at Google. Prior to Google, he was a software engineer at Microsoft. Rudy earned a bachelor's degree in computer engineering from Northwestern University.

speakers.name: Sumantro Das
speakers.role: Director, Product Innovation and Growth Brands
speakers.bio: Sumo is the Director of Product Innovation and Growth Brands. He is responsible for discovering new technologies and building new customer experiences and brands to drive growth at 1800Flowers. He is the GM of the international business division and Personalization Universe customized gifts brand and is currently leading the launch of the new international delivery brand, 0800Flowers. Sumo chairs the Mobile Roundtable which is an industry consortium of 35 of the Internet Retailer 100 mobile product and marketing leaders.

speakers.name: Rustam Lalkaka
speakers.bio: Rustam is Director of Product at Cloudflare, focused on building Cloudflare's network into products that make the Internet fast, secure, and reliable. He has previously spent time at early stage health startups and Microsoft. Rustam has a BA in Economics from the University of Wisconsinâ€“Madison.

worklets.name: State of Houdini
worklets.description: Houdini continues to expand the power and capabilities of CSS. Houdini exposes the parts of the CSS engine that make possible APIs like CSS Grid, Scroll Snap Points, conic gradients, et al. Extend CSSâ€™ capabilities yourself without questionable hacks and better performance.  In this talk, we look at the overall structure of the Houdini effort and take a closer look at CSS Paint, Animation Worklets and Custom Layout API. We can get a taste of what the future holds: An ecosystem of modules that bring powerful effects from the shelf to your app.

speakers.name: Surma
speakers.bio: Surma is an engineer working with the Chrome team. He likes to cut himself on the bleeding edge, goes full-stack every once in a while and prefers good code over functional one.

webxr.name: Building Engaging Immersive Experiences
webxr.description: The Web is emerging as an ideal platform for immersive reality experiences, particularly in augmented reality. In this talk, we will cover the progress in the WebXR Device API, show how partners are building compelling augmented reality experiences on the web today, and point you in the right direction to explore this space yourself.

speakers.name: Chris Wilson
speakers.bio: Chris has worked on building the web platform for the past 25 years. He's currently a product manager on the Immersive Web team at Google, as well as co-chair of the Immersive Web Working Group at the W3C.

speakers.name: John Pallett
speakers.bio: John works on augmented reality for the web. His background includes over two decades working on media and 3D graphics software.

wasm.name: Using WebAssembly and Threads
wasm.description: WebAssembly enables new experiences that weâ€™ve never been able to get on the Web before and now WebAssembly threads takes that even further. This talk shows some examples of what WebAssembly enables, highlighting a few real-world examples and demos.  You'll also learn about the tools and debugging capabilities available to help you  take advantage of WebAssembly and threads in your web applications today.

speakers.name: Alex Danilo
speakers.bio: Alex has spent over 15 years on various W3C working groups developing the standards we all know and love, all while running a couple of start ups doing web engines for mobile and embedded markets. He now works at Google, spreading the good word about HTML5 and WebAssembly.

speakers.name: Thomas Nattestad
speakers.bio: Thomas is the Product Manager for V8, WebAssembly, and new web capabilities. He is passionate about enabling developers to meet more user needs through the web platform and expanding what experiences are possible.

virtue-of-laziness.name: The Virtue of Laziness: Leveraging Incrementality for Faster Web UI
virtue-of-laziness.description: If the first rule of performance is "do less," the second is surely "be lazy." Using LitElement-based web components, weâ€™ll explore the use of bleeding-edge techniques and browser APIs to spread work out so that your UI is faster to load, render and respond to user input. Topics weâ€™ll cover include route-based dynamic module loading, async rendering, chunked rendering, IntersectionObserver, display-locking, and scheduling long-running tasks.

speakers.name: Justin Fagnani
speakers.bio: Justin has been working on developer tools for 10 years at Google. He founded the Google App Maker project, worked on Web Components and JavaScript interop for the Dart programming language, and then tools for the Polymer Project. Recently he's been building Polymer's next-generation UI libraries like lit-html and LitElement.

chrome-os.name: Chrome OS: Ready for Web Development
chrome-os.description: Chrome OS not only powers devices from sticks to tablets to desktops, but it can also run web, Android, and now Linux applications, making Chromebooks premier machines for web development.  This talk provides a high-level overview of Chrome OS and discusses core and new features available to Web Developers. Topics include best practices for web development, including Progressive Web Apps, and optimizing input and touch for tablets, while having desktop users in mind.

speakers.name: Dan Dascalescu
speakers.bio: Dan Dascalescu is a Partner Developer Advocate at Google, specializing in web technologies and helping partners build excellent web experiences. Prior to Google, Dan has co-founded two web startups (in EdTech and FinTech), the Quantified Self Forum (the largest online community for self-trackers), and Blueseed (the visa-free startup ship for entrepreneurs). Dan studied Computer Science in Romania and scored 2nd place nationwide at the Olympiad in Informatics. He is a supporter of open source software, transhumanism, and seasteading.

376ad68795360ead7e20ee6892bf4e0e.name: Ben Galbraith
376ad68795360ead7e20ee6892bf4e0e.bio: Ben Galbraith is the Product Management Director for the Web Platform at Google. His past roles have included heading Product and Design for Walmart Global eCommerce as well as leadership roles at HP / Palm, Mozilla, MediaOcean, and several startups. Ben has been writing code since he was six and started his first business at ten. He lives in Palo Alto with his wife and eight children.

He works on tools, services, and libraries that aim to make it easier for developers to build successful products that load fast and delight users. He also enjoys working with developers throughout the ecosystem, across many of Googleâ€™s Web initiatives beyond Chrome itself. Previously, he has enjoyed building software products and platforms from his own startups to companies such as Mozilla (developer tools), Palm (webOS), and Walmart Labs (VPE for native mobile and Web).

9d58776bf96aa22e9e2363eced6ae56a.name: Aanchal Bahadur
9d58776bf96aa22e9e2363eced6ae56a.bio: Aanchal Bahadur has been at Google for eight years, contributing to the core of Google's scale in Ad Operations and managing talented YouTube creators on the Creator and Artist Development Partnerships team in India. For the past three years, she's been leading business development for Chrome/Web Platform driving adoption for modern web tech including - PWAs (#modernweb), web media (#nobuffering), and AMP4Email (#dynamicmail), to move the open web platform forward. In her free time, you'll find her reading, writing, or having a conversation about how dogs > people.

990ee931a6b71e49a5bac2bded6b0e0e.name: Paul Irish
990ee931a6b71e49a5bac2bded6b0e0e.bio: Paul Irish is a front-end developer who loves the Web. He works on Lighthouse, Chrome DevTools, and performance metrics. Elizabeth Sweeny is a product manager on the Chrome Platform team, working on Lighthouse, CrUX, and other developer insights products.

a2c1714713a8b398ee3a0887ccf47699.name: Elizabeth Sweeny
a2c1714713a8b398ee3a0887ccf47699.bio: Elizabeth Sweeny is a product manager on the Chrome Platform team, working on Lighthouse, CrUX, and other developer insights products.

0933dea74b5231e219a02dfb99156d93.name: Houssein Djirdeh
0933dea74b5231e219a02dfb99156d93.bio: Houssein works on the performance team at Chrome. He is passionate about progressive enhancement and building for the mobile web.

4ca9cd2e993fcdf70686c21c8ae83260.name: Katie Hempenius
4ca9cd2e993fcdf70686c21c8ae83260.bio: Katie is an engineer working on making the Web faster with the Chrome team. Previously, she built things for Google Ad Exchange and Fitbit.

7ec68f6b36d6f1f9105344b65d92c959.name: Ewa Gasperowicz
7ec68f6b36d6f1f9105344b65d92c959.bio: Ewa is a developer platform engineer at Google Web team. A front-end engineer, focused mainly on making the Web faster and more user friendly. Interested in Progressive Web Apps development and analysis, EWA is always keen to investigate common scenarios and emerging app design patterns.

209890681f391c4f768dba10db86376c.name: Phil Walton
209890681f391c4f768dba10db86376c.bio: Philip is a senior developer programs engineer for Chrome with a focus on web performance and tooling. Prior to working at Google, Philip was lead front-end software engineer at AppFolio where he built component libraries and tools for a variety of different web teams. Philip also has experience working in agencies, with non-profit organizations, and as a freelancer.

d035cf5e776a360ca4fa5eab76bb5a19.bio: Jason is with Web DevRel at Google, working on making the Web faster. Created Preact and a few other things.

3b75cdd826a16f5bba0076690f644dc7.bio: Adam is a UX Engineer on Google Cloud; Developer += Designer; parentNode + 2 leafs; CSS/JS addict; fullstack+Ui hax0r; repeat(âˆž, [empathize, define, design, develop, deploy]); ðŸ––

bf62d98d0284b3b873ed50fdd1697704.name: Jake Archibald
bf62d98d0284b3b873ed50fdd1697704.bio: Jake works in Google Chromeâ€™s developer relations team, working on specs, testing implementations, and ensuring developers have tools to make their jobs less painful. Heâ€™s a big fan of time-to-render optimisations, progressive enhancement, and all of that responsive stuff.

c6e3690d5aaca6e349bc63d40729411d.name: Mariko Kosaka
c6e3690d5aaca6e349bc63d40729411d.bio: Mariko Kosaka is a software engineer who loves data and knitting. When she is not coding applications for other people, she uses code to help her design textiles, and organize local meetup BrooklynJS.

48a4de34ba8674542200b5c10935f148.name: FranÃ§ois Beaufort
48a4de34ba8674542200b5c10935f148.bio: He loves to dive into Chromium source code and share his findings.

531e7c79b602cb57c6192c9dd40f53b8.name: Cheney Tsai

He works closely with top partners to adopt modern web technologies (like PWA and AMP) and raise the bar of mobile UX. Prior to Google, Cheney was an engineer at Pickie (acquired by RetailMeNot) and a consultant at Deloitte.

44cfd5d8bf53a3b59ad8c8cd8d43dc7f.bio: Alberto Medina is a Developer Advocate in the Web Content Ecosystems Team at Google, focusing on AMP, Progressive Technologies, and Content Management Systems. Alberto is a Computer Scientist by training and has worked in academic environments, research labs, startups, medium companies (~300M users), and large companies (~1B+ users). Passionate about enabling awesome web experiences for all users.

16b1480cf3745ca7c6e3fad897869a6d.name: Weston Ruter
16b1480cf3745ca7c6e3fad897869a6d.bio: Weston Ruter is a Developer Programs Engineer working on the Content Ecosystems team at Google. For the past decade he has worked extensively with WordPress, including the development of extensions and leading a release of the core CMS. During the past year he has been working to improve the user experience for a third of the Web by advancing AMP and PWA in WordPress.

891044520f379343f3bb5add2a80550b.name: Martin Splitt
891044520f379343f3bb5add2a80550b.bio: Martin is a developer advocate on the Webmaster Trends Analyst team at Google Switzerland.  In this role, he helps developers and content creators to build great content on the Web. He is involved with the W3C as well as the global web and JavaScript developer community, working to keep the Web open.

d87d78a8275351c3154c3232ac2284af.name: Tom Greenaway
d87d78a8275351c3154c3232ac2284af.bio: Tom Greenaway is a Developer Advocate for Chrome & the Web. His focus is on web & HTML gaming. He is also an expert on the indexability of JavaScript-powered websites. Before joining Google he ran his own independent game development studio and created the multi award-winning mobile game "Duet" which was downloaded over 15 million times.

eda7396f5f2511df0646ce0e54401981.name: Malte Ubl
eda7396f5f2511df0646ce0e54401981.bio: Malte is a Principal Engineer at Google working on JavaScript infrastructure, a member of the AMP Project Technical Steering Committee, and helps curate JSConf EU in Berlin.

9479c85721d840f07b253c2f98e874f9.name: Nicole Sullivan
9479c85721d840f07b253c2f98e874f9.bio: Nicole is a PM on Chrome at Google. OOCSS, CSSLint, Smush It, Dr Frankenstyle, typeOmatic. CSSConf founder, author, speaker.

b69255cf1077fbad80ada26a75ea3601.name: Eric Bidelman
b69255cf1077fbad80ada26a75ea3601.bio: Eric is a senior staff engineer at Google working with the Chrome team on web projects like Puppeteer, headless Chrome, Lighthouse, Polymer, and web components. He's the author of "Using the HTML5 Filesystem API," and has led front-end projects like the Google I/O web app, Google's Santa tracker, chromestatus.com, and html5rocks.com. Prior to Google, Eric worked as a software engineer at the University of Michigan where he designed rich web applications and APIs for the university's 19 libraries.

fcac115effef3e009c86b70f58b55a18.name: Natasha Pabrai
fcac115effef3e009c86b70f58b55a18.bio: Natasha joined the Chrome team this past January and expanded her focus from enterprise cloud security to web platform development.   Prior to joining Chrome, she lead several security programs for GSuite. Before joining Google, Natasha lead several security programs at Salesforce, IBM, and a small startup called Reflexion Health.

c02915a65496ddfb2542c6fe2d80bcf3.name: Gray Norton
c02915a65496ddfb2542c6fe2d80bcf3.bio: Gray is a passionate Web advocate and an engineering manager on the Chrome team. Prior to joining Google he led the framework team at webOS, helping developers build apps for several generations of phones, tablets, TVs and watches. In past lives, he has worked on software tools for creating chatbots, 3D games and pretty pictures. When not at work, Gray enjoys spending time with his family and occasionally singing.

e0882402cfa59b5a2200eea5b49b4616.name: Shubhie Panicker
e0882402cfa59b5a2200eea5b49b4616.bio: Shubhie Panicker, Staff Software Engineer driving performance related efforts on Chromeâ€™s Web Platform team -- working on web standards and chromium implementation. Prior to Chrome, she worked on server infrastructure and web frameworks for products like Google Search, Google Photos, and so on.

b755b54531c5363b0907e46e90892c5b.name: Paul Lewis
b755b54531c5363b0907e46e90892c5b.bio: Prior to Chrome, she worked on server infrastructure and web frameworks for products like Google Search, Google Photos etc.

33a6f8441ba820f7ec2c6f9dea283e18.name: Surma
33a6f8441ba820f7ec2c6f9dea283e18.bio: Surma is an engineer working with the Chrome team. He likes to cut himself on the bleeding edge, goes full-stack every once in a while and prefers good code over functional one.

548a8839a94bfe61a436f8ce9ec380a7.name: Kinuko Yasuda
548a8839a94bfe61a436f8ce9ec380a7.bio: Kinuko is a software engineer at Google working on Chrome. She is leading loading related implementation projects for Chrome, like Service Workers, Web Packaging, and various loading improvements.

92db3e5999f3dc0016b626ee57b7dbf8.name: Rudy Galfi
92db3e5999f3dc0016b626ee57b7dbf8.bio: Rudy Galfi is the lead product manager for the AMP Project at Google. Prior to Google, he was a software engineer at Microsoft. Rudy earned a bachelor's degree in computer engineering from Northwestern University.

d0fe1ce07fddde1b8c7da18df6333942.name: Chris Wilson
d0fe1ce07fddde1b8c7da18df6333942.bio: Chris has worked on building the web platform for the past 25 years. He's currently a product manager on the Immersive Web team at Google, as well as co-chair of the Immersive Web Working Group at the W3C.

85dd771aea95331dfcad8cbbacbd2d37.name: John Pallett
85dd771aea95331dfcad8cbbacbd2d37.bio: John works on augmented reality for the web. His background includes over two decades working on media and 3D graphics software.

3b562519931363f27d26b9c24464b5e9.name: Alex Danilo
3b562519931363f27d26b9c24464b5e9.bio: Alex has spent over 15 years on various W3C working groups developing the standards we all know and love, all while running a couple of start ups doing web engines for mobile and embedded markets. He now works at Google, spreading the good word about HTML5 and WebAssembly.

673e7995b41f041a67fff425b6c6f824.name: Thomas Nattestad
673e7995b41f041a67fff425b6c6f824.bio: Thomas is the Product Manager for V8, WebAssembly, and new web capabilities. He is passionate about enabling developers to meet more user needs through the web platform and expanding what experiences are possible.

7ffdb3da8ce9da2d0eb62d731eaae1b5.name: Justin Fagnani
7ffdb3da8ce9da2d0eb62d731eaae1b5.bio: Justin has been working on developer tools for 10 years at Google. He founded the Google App Maker project, worked on Web Components and JavaScript interop for the Dart programming language, and then tools for the Polymer Project. Recently he's been building Polymer's next-generation UI libraries like lit-html and LitElement.

f0cac071f7b18661ec0aa0589a59d1da.name: Dan Dascalescu
f0cac071f7b18661ec0aa0589a59d1da.bio: Dan Dascalescu is a Partner Developer Advocate at Google, specializing in web technologies and helping partners build excellent web experiences. Prior to Google, Dan has co-founded two web startups (in EdTech and FinTech), the Quantified Self Forum (the largest online community for self-trackers), and Blueseed (the visa-free startup ship for entrepreneurs). Dan studied Computer Science in Romania and scored 2nd place nationwide at the Olympiad in Informatics. He is a supporter of open source software, transhumanism, and seasteading.

ee74708b5aba7056bc4621495b3f2f2f.name: Angie Bird
ee74708b5aba7056bc4621495b3f2f2f.bio: Angie is a software engineer in Google. She has been working on AV1 core design for more than three years. Prior to her software engineering career at Google, she studied in the Computer Science Master Program at NYU.

480407ea47efd1aa2d14fb007fee6f36.name: Jason Chase
480407ea47efd1aa2d14fb007fee6f36.bio: Jason leads a Chrome team that helps developers understand and control the features available on the web platform. Prior to Google, Jason was building enterprise-class systems delivered on the web, experiencing the challenges of web development directly. Jason has computer science degrees (BMath, MMath) from the University of Waterloo.

b259ae8c7193c2ea501456cdbcfcc22c.name: Zack Argyle
b259ae8c7193c2ea501456cdbcfcc22c.bio: Zack Argyle leads the web platform team at Pinterest with a deep passion for fast, engaging PWAs.

0d3daad691d2ecf0ba8c58cc844d9213.name: David Brunelle
0d3daad691d2ecf0ba8c58cc844d9213.bio: David is an engineering leader who believes in the ability of digital products to improve the lives of people in both big and small ways. Heâ€™s been building products for the Web since the days of table-based layouts and transparent gifs. Today, David leads the Starbucks digital products engineering team where he is focused on extending the Starbucks experience to all of the digital touch points that matter to Starbucksâ€™ customers including web, native, and voice.

b54ae377534372a44ef007e79524a128.name: Matt Rizzo
b54ae377534372a44ef007e79524a128.bio: Matt Rizzo is a Senior Product Manager on the Growth Opportunities team at Spotify. His teamâ€™s focus is on using the power of the Web to drive sustained user growth around the world. Most recently, his team launched a mobile web Spotify player to extend access beyond native apps. In his free time, Matt enjoys running and cheering on the New York Knicks.

6c7c22f7756e42403829f400418da068.name: Sumantro Das
6c7c22f7756e42403829f400418da068.role: Director, Product Innovation and Growth Brands
6c7c22f7756e42403829f400418da068.bio: Sumo is the Director of Product Innovation and Growth Brands. He is responsible for discovering new technologies and building new customer experiences and brands to drive growth at 1800Flowers. He is the GM of the international business division and Personalization Universe customized gifts brand and is currently leading the launch of the new international delivery brand, 0800Flowers. Sumo chairs the Mobile Roundtable which is an industry consortium of 35 of the Internet Retailer 100 mobile product and marketing leaders.

0e9ac15d6e92d22c6d8fca4395ae71a1.name: Rustam Lalkaka
0e9ac15d6e92d22c6d8fca4395ae71a1.bio: Rustam is Director of Product at Cloudflare, focused on building Cloudflare's network into products that make the Internet fast, secure, and reliable. He has previously spent time at early stage health startups and Microsoft. Rustam has a BA in Economics from the University of Wisconsinâ€“Madison.
